respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2013), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

publicationStmt.publisher: Textual Communities and the Canterbury Tales Project, University of Saskatchewan

licence.p: All republication of all or any part of this transcript must credit its creators and all who have contributed to it, as listed in the sourceDesc element, and make available free-to-all any work derived from this resource under the same license.
Commercial republication is permitted, in accordance with these terms.

respStmt.name: Transcription: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo and members of the Canterbury Tales Project at Oxford and Sheffield (1992-1998), De Montfort University, Leicester (1998-2005), Birmingham (2005-2010), Saskatoon (2010-2014), Virginia Tech, New York University, University of Murcia, Adam Mickiewicz University (Poznan) and Brigham Young University.

Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.
De Montfort team; conversion for Textual Communities: Saskatchewan team.

msIdentifier.repository: Columbia University, Rare Book and Manuscript Library

div.l: EY god mercy sayde our oste tho
Now suche awyff y pᵃy god kepe me fro
Lo suche shleyghthe and sbtilites
As wēmmen ben for and as bysy as bees
Beth they vs foly men for to disceyue
And fro asoth euer woleth they weyue
By this marchauntes tale hit ꝓproueth wel
But douteles as trewe as eny steel
I haue awyf thauȝgh she pore be
But of hur tonge alabbyng shrewe is she
And she hath an hepe of vices mo
Ther of no fors let al suche thynges go
But wyte ȝe what in conseill be hit said
Me reweth sore that I am to hur tyed
For and I shulde rykene euery vies
Whyche that she hath y wys I nere noȝt wyse
And cause why for hit shulde reported be
And tolde to hur of some of this meygne
Of whom hit nedeth noȝt to declar
Sthe wymen con oute wel suche chaffar
ke my wit suffiseth noȝt therto
elle al ther fore my tale is do
S frankeleyn com nerr ȝef it ȝour wille be
And say vs atale for certes ȝe
Ȝe can ther on as meche as eny man
Nay syr ꝙquod he I wol say as I can
With hertly will for I wol noȝt rebell
A ȝaynes ȝour wil atale wol I tell
Haueth me excused ȝef I say amys
My will is good and lo my tale is this
This olde gentil Brytons in here dayes
Of diuers auentures maden layes
Rymeyde first in hur Briton tonge
Whiche layes with her instrumentes they songe
Or elles redyng hem for her plesaunce
And oon of hem haue I in remambraunce
Whiche I shal say with good will as I can
But sires by cause that I am a berell man
At my by gynnyng first I ȝow by seche
Haueth me excused of my rude speche
I lerned neuer retoryk certayn
Thyng that I speke hit mot be bare and pleyn
I shleppte neủer/re vpon the mounte of ꝐPer/Parnaso
Ne I lerned neủer/re Marcus tullius Cytthero
Ne colours knowe I noon with outen drede
But suche colours as growen in amede
Or elles suche as men dye or peynte
Colours of retoryk ben to queynte
My spirit feleth noȝt of suche matr
But ȝeff ȝow luste my tale shall ȝe her
Ther was a knyȝt that loued and dede his peyne
In armorike that called was brytaynne
To serue alady in his beste wyse
And mony alabour and mony agret empryse
He for his lady wrouȝte er she wer wonne
For she was oon the faireste vnder sonne
And eken ther to comen of so heyȝ kynrede
That wel vnnethe durste this knyȝt for drede
Telle hur his wo his peyne and his distresse
But at the laste she for his worthynesse
And namely for his mekely obeysaunce
Hath suche apite cauȝt of his plesaunce
That pryuely she fel at his acord
To take hym for her housbond and her lord
For suche lorshipe as men han ouer her wyfes
And forto leden the more in blisse her lyfes
Of his freo will he swor hur as a knyȝt
That neuer he in al his lyue day ne nyȝt
Ne shulde vpon hym take no maystry
Aȝaynes hur wyll kythe hur gelousye
But hur obeye and folewe hur will in al
As eny louer to his lady shal
Saue that the name of soủer/reeyngte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degre
Than sawe he knyȝtes Iosten in aplayn
And after this he dede hym suche plesaunce
That he hym shewyd his lady in adaunce
On whiche hym selfe daunced as hym thouȝt
And when this mayster that this magyke wrouȝt
Sawe hit was tyme he clapped his hondes to
And fare wel al þe reuel is ago
And ȝet remewed neủer/re out of his hous
Whiles they sawe al this syȝt merueylous
But in his studye ther as his bokes be
They satyn still and no whyȝt but they thr
To hym this maister called hys squier
And sayde hym thu is redy our soper
Almoste an hour hit is I vndurtake
Sethes I ȝow bade our soꝑper/par to make
When that these worthy wenten with me
Vnto my study ther as my bokes be
Sir ꝙquod this squier when hit lyketh ȝow
Hit is al redy thaugh ȝe wolden hit now
Go we then soupe ꝙquod he and for the beste
his amerous folk som tyme wold ha reste
ut after soꝑper/par ful they in trete
That some shulde this maistres gwon be
To remewe alle the rokkes of brytayne
And eke fro geroıı̄un to the mouthe of sayne
He made hym strange and wor so god hym saue
Lesse than athousand pond he nolde noȝt haue
Ne gladly for that some ne Bolde he gon
Aurelius with blisful herte anoon
Onswerde thus fy on athousand pond
This wyde world whiche that men say is ronde
I wolde hit ȝeue ȝef I wer lord of hit
This bargeyn is ful dryuen for we ben knyȝt
Ȝe shullen ben I payed trewly by my trouthe
But loketh now that for no neclygence ne for shlouthe
Ȝe tary vs no leynger then to morewe
Nay ꝙquod this clerke hier my trouthe to borewe
To bedde is gon Aurelyus when hym luste
And wel neygh al that nyȝt he hade his reste
What for his labour and for his hope of blysse
His woful herte of penaunce gan to lysse
Vpon the morewe when that his was day
To Brytayne took they the riȝt way
Aurelyus and this magicien by syde
And ben descendet ther they woleth abyde
And this was as this bokes me remembr
The colde forsty seson of decembr
Phebus wax old and hewed lyke latoıı̄un
That in his hoot declynacon
Shoon as the Bornysshed gold with stremes bryȝt
But now in Caprycorn adon he
Wher as he shoon ful pale I dar wel sayn
The bitter frostes with the snowe and reyn
Distruyed hath the grene in euery ȝerd
Ianus sitte by the fuyr with double berd
And drynketh of his bugle horn the wyn
By foren hym stand braiae of the teuxid swyn
And nowel cryeth euer lusty man
Aurelyus
Doth to his r chere and reuerence
And preyeth hym to don his diligence
To bryngen hym out of his peynes smert
Or with a swerd that he wolde shlitte his hert
This subtill clerk whiche routhe hath of this man
That nyȝt and day he sped hem that he can
To wayte atyme of his conclusyoıı̄un
This is to sayn to make illusyoıı̄un
The whiche an apparens in iogellrye
I can no termes of astrologye
That she and euery wyȝt shulde wene and saye
That of Brytayne the rokkes wer aweye
Or elles wer sonke vnder grounde
So at the laste hath hys tyme yfounde
To make his iapes and his wrechednes
Of whiche a substicious cursednes
